10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-013-9834-9983410.1007/s10904-013-9834-9ArticleHydrothermal Synthesis, Crystal Structure and Characterization of a Novel threefold Interpenetrating lvt Framework Based on a 104-Membered [Cd(Bix)] 816+ RingDanFei-Jun1LiCai1LiDong-Sheng1cMuYi-Qiang1YangJing-Jing1ZhaoJun1grid.254148.e0000000100336389College of Mechanical & Material Engineering, Research Institute of Materials, China Three Gorges University443002YichangChina+86-717-6397516+86-717-6397516lidongsheng1@126.com22201332013232446451231201331120121262012222013© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20132013Abstract

A novel threefold interpenetrating coordination framework {[Cd2(bix)4(SCN)4]}n (1) [bix = 1, 4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene] was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction of Cd(OAc)2·2H2O, bix and NaSCN. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In 1, the bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link Cd(II) centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ sub-uints. Through the shared Cd(II, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a new 3D threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.

Graphical Abstract

A novel 3D threefold interpenetrated lvt coordination framework{[Cd2(bix)4(SCN)4]}n, based on rare 104-membered ring [Cd(bix)]816+ with chair-configuration, has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized. Moreover, the thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 were also investigated.

Introduction

Hybrid inorganic–organic compounds represent a new generation of solid-state materials, which have promising applications in gas storage, catalysis, adsorption, magnetism, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, and sensors [1–4]. Entangled systems (interpenetrating, catenanes, rotaxanes, self-penetrating, and molecular knots), a unique class of hybrid inorganic–organic compounds, have attracted considerable interest because of their intriguing topological structures and potential applications [5, 6]. In the realm of entanglement, interpenetrating networks can be regarded as infinite, ordered polycatenanes or polyrotaxanes, and are characterized by the presence of two or more independent networks that are inextricably entangled through the rings belonging to one framework [6]. A variety of interpenetrating frameworks have been constructed and are discussed in several excellent reviews [6–10]. However, despite the remarkable achievements in this highly active research area, to predict and accurately control interpenetrating structures still remains a considerable challenge due to the relative unpredictability of the subtle assembly process, including the nature of the organic ligand, metal ion, solvent system, pH value of the solution and the metal-to-ligand ratio, any or all of which may influence the structures of coordination frameworks [11–13]. Among these factors, the organic ligands play a crucial role in framework construction owing to their ability to offer different charge balance requirements, flexible linking modes, and orientation of donor groups. Therefore, the reasonable design of a ligand is usually a useful and important way to study the controlled synthesis of such architectures [14].

Recent studies have further demonstrated that coordination systems assembled by N,N’ donor ligands, especially those with both flexible and rigid portions, will show more diverse and interesting polymeric networks with potential applications [15, 16]. From this background information, we have focused attention on building coordination frameworks with N,N’-donor ligands such as 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene) (bix) and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (bibp) based on the following considerations [17]; First, the flexible parts, {–(CH2)–}, could tolerate a large structural twist and acquire the desirable coordination environment for the metal ions. Second, the rigid parts (i.e., phenyl ring or biphenyl backbone) could increase weak interactions in the coordination frameworks, thereby facilitating the formation of a supramolecular arrangement [18, 19]. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, topological analysis and photoluminescence property of a new threefold interpenetrating 3D coordination polymer formulated as {[Cd4(bix)8(SCN)8]}n (1) involving the bix ligand with a Cd(II) salt.

ExperimentalMaterials and General Methods

All solvents and reagents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. The FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FTIR Nexus spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N was performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series II analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns for microcrystalline samples were measured on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2 deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The calculated PXRD patterns were obtained from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was taken on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in an atmosphere of nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

Preparation of [Cd<sub>4</sub>(bix)<sub>8</sub>(SCN)<sub>8</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Cd(OAc)2·2H2O (26.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaSCN (8.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), bix (23.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), H2O (6 mL), and 0.2 M NaOH (1.0 mL) solution was stirred in air for 0.5-h. The solution was transferred to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner and heated at 120 °C for 120-h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature and pale yellow block crystals were obtained; yield, 58.4 % based on Cd. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C60H56N20S4Cd2: C, 51.10; H, 4.00; N, 19.86; Found: C, 51.03; H, 4.11; N, 20.38. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3136 (w), 2060 (w), 1711 (s), 1605 (s), 1585 (s), 1515 (s), 1389 (s), 1276 (s), 1223 (s), 1117 (m), 934 (s), 825 (m), 777 (m), 715 (s), 698 (s).

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚR radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using φ/ω scan technique at 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multi-scan program SADABS [20]. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [21]. A full-matrix least-squares refinement on F2 was carried out using SHELXL-97 [22]. The H-atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains. Generally, the positions of the C-bound H-atoms were generated by a riding model on idealized geometries. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are listed in Table 1 and Table S1.

Structural Analysis of <bold>1</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ P\bar{1} $$\end{document}, and an asymmetric unit of 1 contains four crystallographically unique Cd(II)-atoms, in which their occupancy is all normal 0.5, four bix ligands and four SCN− anions. All Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3 bivalent cations show both an octahedral coordination geometry {CdN6}, which is completed with four N-atoms from four bix ligands, and two N-atoms from two SCN− anions (Cd–N = 2.274(6)–2.400(7) Å) (Fig. 1a, b). The Cd4 bivalent cation is coordinated to four bix ligands via N-atoms (Cd–N = 2.261(6) and 2.360(7) Å) and two SCN− anions via S-atoms (Cd–S = 2.877(3) Å) (Fig. 1b). The Cd(II)–N and Cd(II)–S distances are normal [23, 24] (Table S1).

In 1, four bix ligands adopt both an overall gauche-configuration but different conformational parameters such as N–Csp3···Csp3–N and Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles, as well as M···M and Ndonor···Ndonor distances (Fig. 2; Table 2). In this way, eight Cd(II)-ions are linked through four pairs bix bridges (labeled as A, B, C and D in Fig. 2) to form a rare centrosymmetric, 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)] 816+(Fig. 3), in the sequence -Cd4-bixC–Cd2-bixB-Cd1-bixA-Cd3-bixD-Cd4-. Here, eight Cd(II) cations ocupy the corners and serve as an octagonal vertex and four pair bix ligands make up eight edges (edge distances: Cd1···Cd2 13.671 Å, Cd3···Cd1 13.444 Å, Cd2···Cd4 13.122 Å and Cd4···Cd3 13.239 Å) (Figs. 3, 4). Notably, the SCN− groups hang on both sides of each octagonal Cd(II) vertex by coordination to S- and N-atoms (Fig. 1). In other words, the resulting large ring may be described as the construction of eight linear [-Cd-bix-]2+ ‘edge’ units held together by eight Cd(II) ion hinge subunits (Fig. 2). A structural analysis reveals that the 104-membered ring shows a chair-configuration, where the dihedral angle of chair plane (67.28°) is defined by three pairs of Cd(II) ions (i.e., 2Cd2, 2Cd3 and 2Cd4) and the parallel plane formed by three Cd(II) ions (i.e., Cd1, Cd2 and Cd3). To our knowledge, such centrosymmetric 104-membered ring holding chair-configuration is quite unusual in metal–organic compounds.

Another striking feature of 1 is the presence of an entangled motif between nine 104-membered rings (1 + 8); i.e., through shared Cd(II), each 104-membered ring is connected with other eight adjacent 104-membered rings (Fig. 4a–c)]. In this way, these 104-membered rings are interlinked to give a 3D coordination framework (Fig. 4d). Owing to the large available space, three such 3D networks interpenetrate each other into a threefold framework. Topologically, each Cd(II) ion acts as a square four-connected node, while each bix serves as a 2-connecter spacer. Thus, whole framework of 1 is a threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework (Fig. 4e, f). An analysis of the interpenetration fashion with the TOPOS program [25] reveals that it belongs to class Ia with the translating interpenetration vector being equal to the a axis (9.43 Å).

XPRD and Thermogravimetric Analysis

The XRPD was used to confirm the phase purity of bulk materials of 1 at room temperature (Fig. 5). Although the experimental pattern shows several unindexed or slightly broadened diffraction peaks relative to those simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk synthesized material represents the pure phase of 1. There was no evidence of crystal decay during X-ray data collection for 1, which is stable at ambient conditions.

The TGA of 1 was performed in air from 30 to 800 °C. The TGA curve shows that the anhydrous 1 is stable to 245 °C. The framework of 1 gradually collapses on further heating and probably corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands (Fig. 6).

Luminescent Property

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have been extensively investigated for fluorescence properties with potential applications as chemical sensors, in photochemistry, and as light emitting diodes [26, 27]. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescent spectrum of 1 was measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense emission band at 461 nm (λex = 352 nm) (Fig. 7). Relative to the free bix ligand (maxima at 359 nm upon excitation 318 nm [28]), the emission maxima of 1 is changed. Since the CdII ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce, the emission peak for 1 is neither a metal-to-ligand nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer in nature, but may arise from π* → π transitions of the bix ligand. As evidence, a similar peak appears for other complexes containing bix ligand [28–30].

Conclusions

A novel 3D threefold interpenetrated lvt coordination framework, which is constructed from a rare 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)]816+, with a chair configuration was synthesized and characterized. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link CdII centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ subuints. Through the shared CdII, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a 3D threefold interpenetrating lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.

The Cd4 bivalent cation is coordinated to four bix ligands via N-atoms (Cd-N = 2.261(6) and 2.360(7) Å) and two SCN- anions via S-atoms (Cd-S = 2.877(3) Å) (Fig. 1b). The Cd(II)-N and Cd(II)-S distances are normal [23, 24] (Table S1).In 1, four bix ligands adopt both an overall gauche-configuration but different conformational parameters such as N-Csp3⋅⋅⋅Csp3-N and Ndonor⋅⋅⋅N-Csp3⋅⋅⋅Csp3 torsion angles, as well as M⋅⋅⋅M and Ndonor⋅⋅⋅Ndonor distances (Fig. 2; Table 2). In this way, eight Cd(II)-ions are linked through four pairs bix bridges (labeled as A, B, C and D in Fig. 2) to form a rare centrosymmetric, 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)] 816+(Fig. 3), in the sequence -Cd4-bixC-Cd2-bixB-Cd1-bixA-Cd3-bixD-Cd4-. Here, eight Cd(II) cations ocupy the corners and serve as an octagonal vertex and four pair bix ligands make up eight edges (edge distances: Cd1⋅⋅⋅Cd2 13.671 Å, Cd3⋅⋅⋅Cd1 13.444 Å, Cd2⋅⋅⋅Cd4 13.122 Å and Cd4⋅⋅⋅Cd3 13.239 Å) (Figs. 3, 4). Notably, the SCN- groups hang on both sides of each octagonal Cd(II) vertex by coordination to S- and N-atoms (Fig. 1). In other words, the resulting large ring may be described as the construction of eight linear [-Cd-bix-]2+ ‘edge' units held together by eight Cd(II) ion hinge subunits (Fig. 2). A structural analysis reveals that the 104-membered ring shows a chair-configuration, where the dihedral angle of chair plane (67.28°) is defined by three pairs of Cd(II) ions (i.e., 2Cd2, 2Cd3 and 2Cd4) and the parallel plane formed by three Cd(II) ions (i.e., Cd1, Cd2 and Cd3). To our knowledge, such centrosymmetric 104-membered ring holding chair-configuration is quite unusual in metal-organic compounds.Another striking feature of 1 is the presence of an entangled motif between nine 104-membered rings (1 + 8); i.e., through shared Cd(II), each 104-membered ring is connected with other eight adjacent 104-membered rings (Fig. 4a-c)]. In this way, these 104-membered rings are interlinked to give a 3D coordination framework (Fig. 4d). Owing to the large available space, three such 3D networks interpenetrate each other into a threefold framework. Topologically, each Cd(II) ion acts as a square four-connected node, while each bix serves as a 2-connecter spacer. Thus, whole framework of 1 is a threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework (Fig. 4e, f). An analysis of the interpenetration fashion with the TOPOS program [25] reveals that it belongs to class Ia with the translating interpenetration vector being equal to the a axis (9.43 Å).XPRD and Thermogravimetric AnalysisThe XRPD was used to confirm the phase purity of bulk materials of 1 at room temperature (Fig. 5). Although the experimental pattern shows several unindexed or slightly broadened diffraction peaks relative to those simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk synthesized material represents the pure phase of 1. There was no evidence of crystal decay during X-ray data collection for 1, which is stable at ambient conditions.The TGA of 1 was performed in air from 30 to 800 °C. The TGA curve shows that the anhydrous 1 is stable to 245 °C. The framework of 1 gradually collapses on further heating and probably corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands (Fig. 6).Luminescent PropertyCoordination polymers with d10 metal centers have been extensively investigated for fluorescence properties with potential applications as chemical sensors, in photochemistry, and as light emitting diodes [26, 27]. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescent spectrum of 1 was measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense emission band at 461 nm (λex = 352 nm) (Fig. 7). Relative to the free bix ligand (maxima at 359 nm upon excitation 318 nm [28]), the emission maxima of 1 is changed. Since the CdII ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce, the emission peak for 1 is neither a metal-to-ligand nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer in nature, but may arise from π* → π transitions of the bix ligand. As evidence, a similar peak appears for other complexes containing bix ligand [28-30].ConclusionsA novel 3D threefold interpenetrated lvt coordination framework, which is constructed from a rare 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)]816+, with a chair configuration was synthesized and characterized. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link CdII centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ subuints. Through the shared CdII, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a 3D threefold interpenetrating lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.Supplementary dataAdditional crystallographic data sets for the structures are available through the Cambridge Structural Data Base, as supplementary publication reference number CCDC-864844 for complex 1. Abstract

A novel threefold interpenetrating coordination framework {[Cd2(bix)4(SCN)4]}n (1) [bix = 1, 4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene] was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction of Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O, bix and NaSCN. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In 1, the bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link Cd(II) centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ sub-uints. Through the shared Cd(II, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a new 3D threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.

Moreover, the thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 were also investigated.

elements.content: Hybrid inorganic–organic compounds represent a new generation of solid-state materials, which have promising applications in gas storage, catalysis, adsorption, magnetism, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, and sensors [1–4]. Entangled systems (interpenetrating, catenanes, rotaxanes, self-penetrating, and molecular knots), a unique class of hybrid inorganic–organic compounds, have attracted considerable interest because of their intriguing topological structures and potential applications [5, 6]. In the realm of entanglement, interpenetrating networks can be regarded as infinite, ordered polycatenanes or polyrotaxanes, and are characterized by the presence of two or more independent networks that are inextricably entangled through the rings belonging to one framework [6]. A variety of interpenetrating frameworks have been constructed and are discussed in several excellent reviews [6–10]. However, despite the remarkable achievements in this highly active research area, to predict and accurately control interpenetrating structures still remains a considerable challenge due to the relative unpredictability of the subtle assembly process, including the nature of the organic ligand, metal ion, solvent system, pH value of the solution and the metal-to-ligand ratio, any or all of which may influence the structures of coordination frameworks [11–13]. Among these factors, the organic ligands play a crucial role in framework construction owing to their ability to offer different charge balance requirements, flexible linking modes, and orientation of donor groups. Therefore, the reasonable design of a ligand is usually a useful and important way to study the controlled synthesis of such architectures [14].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hybrid inorganic-organic compounds represent a new generation of solid-state materials, which have promising applications in gas storage, catalysis, adsorption, magnetism, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, and sensors [1-4]. Entangled systems (interpenetrating, catenanes, rotaxanes, self-penetrating, and molecular knots), a unique class of hybrid inorganic-organic compounds, have attracted considerable interest because of their intriguing topological structures and potential applications [5, 6]. In the realm of entanglement, interpenetrating networks can be regarded as infinite, ordered polycatenanes or polyrotaxanes, and are characterized by the presence of two or more independent networks that are inextricably entangled through the rings belonging to one framework [6]. A variety of interpenetrating frameworks have been constructed and are discussed in several excellent reviews [6-10]. However, despite the remarkable achievements in this highly active research area, to predict and accurately control interpenetrating structures still remains a considerable challenge due to the relative unpredictability of the subtle assembly process, including the nature of the organic ligand, metal ion, solvent system, pH value of the solution and the metal-to-ligand ratio, any or all of which may influence the structures of coordination frameworks [11-13]. Among these factors, the organic ligands play a crucial role in framework construction owing to their ability to offer different charge balance requirements, flexible linking modes, and orientation of donor groups. Therefore, the reasonable design of a ligand is usually a useful and important way to study the controlled synthesis of such architectures [14].

elements.content: Recent studies have further demonstrated that coordination systems assembled by N,N’ donor ligands, especially those with both flexible and rigid portions, will show more diverse and interesting polymeric networks with potential applications [15, 16]. From this background information, we have focused attention on building coordination frameworks with N,N’-donor ligands such as 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene) (bix) and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (bibp) based on the following considerations [17]; First, the flexible parts, {–(CH2)–}, could tolerate a large structural twist and acquire the desirable coordination environment for the metal ions. Second, the rigid parts (i.e., phenyl ring or biphenyl backbone) could increase weak interactions in the coordination frameworks, thereby facilitating the formation of a supramolecular arrangement [18, 19]. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, topological analysis and photoluminescence property of a new threefold interpenetrating 3D coordination polymer formulated as {[Cd4(bix)8(SCN)8]}n (1) involving the bix ligand with a Cd(II) salt.
elements.clean_text: Recent studies have further demonstrated that coordination systems assembled by N,N' donor ligands, especially those with both flexible and rigid portions, will show more diverse and interesting polymeric networks with potential applications [15, 16]. From this background information, we have focused attention on building coordination frameworks with N,N'-donor ligands such as 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene) (bix) and 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (bibp) based on the following considerations [17]; First, the flexible parts, {-(CH2)-}, could tolerate a large structural twist and acquire the desirable coordination environment for the metal ions. Second, the rigid parts (i.e., phenyl ring or biphenyl backbone) could increase weak interactions in the coordination frameworks, thereby facilitating the formation of a supramolecular arrangement [18, 19]. Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, topological analysis and photoluminescence property of a new threefold interpenetrating 3D coordination polymer formulated as {[Cd4(bix)8(SCN)8]}n (1) involving the bix ligand with a Cd(II) salt.

elements.content: All solvents and reagents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. The FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FTIR Nexus spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N was performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series II analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns for microcrystalline samples were measured on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2 deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The calculated PXRD patterns were obtained from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was taken on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in an atmosphere of nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and General Methods

All solvents and reagents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. The FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FTIR Nexus spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns for microcrystalline samples were measured on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2 deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The calculated PXRD patterns were obtained from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was taken on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in an atmosphere of nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(OAc)2·2H2O (26.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaSCN (8.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), bix (23.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), H2O (6 mL), and 0.2 M NaOH (1.0 mL) solution was stirred in air for 0.5-h. The solution was transferred to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner and heated at 120 °C for 120-h. Preparation of [Cd4(bix)8(SCN)8] (1)

A mixture of Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O (26.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaSCN (8.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), bix (23.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), H2O (6 mL), and 0.2 M NaOH (1.0 mL) solution was stirred in air for 0.5-h. The solution was transferred to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner and heated at 120 °C for 120-h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature and pale yellow block crystals were obtained; yield, 58.4 % based on Cd. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C60H56N20S4Cd2: C, 51.10; H, 4.00; N, 19.86; Found: C, 51.03; H, 4.11; N, 20.38. elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚR radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using φ/ω scan technique at 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multi-scan program SADABS [20]. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [21]. A full-matrix least-squares refinement on F2 was carried out using SHELXL-97 [22]. The H-atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains. Generally, the positions of the C-bound H-atoms were generated by a riding model on idealized geometries. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are listed in Table 1 and Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚR radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using φ/ω scan technique at 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multi-scan program SADABS [20]. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [21]. A full-matrix least-squares refinement on F2 was carried out using SHELXL-97 [22]. The H-atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains. Generally, the positions of the C-bound H-atoms were generated by a riding model on idealized geometries. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are listed in Table 1 and Table S1.

The Cd4 bivalent cation is coordinated to four bix ligands via N-atoms (Cd-N = 2.261(6) and 2.360(7) Å) and two SCN- anions via S-atoms (Cd-S = 2.877(3) Å) (Fig. 1b). The Cd(II)-N and Cd(II)-S distances are normal [23, 24] (Table S1).

elements.content: In 1, four bix ligands adopt both an overall gauche-configuration but different conformational parameters such as N–Csp3···Csp3–N and Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles, as well as M···M and Ndonor···Ndonor distances (Fig. 2; Table 2). In this way, eight Cd(II)-ions are linked through four pairs bix bridges (labeled as A, B, C and D in Fig. 2) to form a rare centrosymmetric, 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)] 816+(Fig. 3), in the sequence -Cd4-bixC–Cd2-bixB-Cd1-bixA-Cd3-bixD-Cd4-. Here, eight Cd(II) cations ocupy the corners and serve as an octagonal vertex and four pair bix ligands make up eight edges (edge distances: Cd1···Cd2 13.671 Å, Cd3···Cd1 13.444 Å, Cd2···Cd4 13.122 Å and Cd4···Cd3 13.239 Å) (Figs. 3, 4). Notably, the SCN− groups hang on both sides of each octagonal Cd(II) vertex by coordination to S- and N-atoms (Fig. 1). In other words, the resulting large ring may be described as the construction of eight linear [-Cd-bix-]2+ ‘edge’ units held together by eight Cd(II) ion hinge subunits (Fig. 2). A structural analysis reveals that the 104-membered ring shows a chair-configuration, where the dihedral angle of chair plane (67.28°) is defined by three pairs of Cd(II) ions (i.e., 2Cd2, 2Cd3 and 2Cd4) and the parallel plane formed by three Cd(II) ions (i.e., Cd1, Cd2 and Cd3). To our knowledge, such centrosymmetric 104-membered ring holding chair-configuration is quite unusual in metal–organic compounds.

In this way, eight Cd(II)-ions are linked through four pairs bix bridges (labeled as A, B, C and D in Fig. 2) to form a rare centrosymmetric, 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)] 816+(Fig. 3), in the sequence -Cd4-bixC-Cd2-bixB-Cd1-bixA-Cd3-bixD-Cd4-. Here, eight Cd(II) cations ocupy the corners and serve as an octagonal vertex and four pair bix ligands make up eight edges (edge distances: Cd1⋅⋅⋅Cd2 13.671 Å, Cd3⋅⋅⋅Cd1 13.444 Å, Cd2⋅⋅⋅Cd4 13.122 Å and Cd4⋅⋅⋅Cd3 13.239 Å) (Figs. 3, 4). Notably, the SCN- groups hang on both sides of each octagonal Cd(II) vertex by coordination to S- and N-atoms (Fig. 1). In other words, the resulting large ring may be described as the construction of eight linear [-Cd-bix-]2+ ‘edge' units held together by eight Cd(II) ion hinge subunits (Fig. 2). A structural analysis reveals that the 104-membered ring shows a chair-configuration, where the dihedral angle of chair plane (67.28°) is defined by three pairs of Cd(II) ions (i.e., 2Cd2, 2Cd3 and 2Cd4) and the parallel plane formed by three Cd(II) ions (i.e., Cd1, Cd2 and Cd3). To our knowledge, such centrosymmetric 104-membered ring holding chair-configuration is quite unusual in metal-organic compounds.

elements.content: Another striking feature of 1 is the presence of an entangled motif between nine 104-membered rings (1 + 8); i.e., through shared Cd(II), each 104-membered ring is connected with other eight adjacent 104-membered rings (Fig. 4a–c)]. In this way, these 104-membered rings are interlinked to give a 3D coordination framework (Fig. 4d). Owing to the large available space, three such 3D networks interpenetrate each other into a threefold framework. Topologically, each Cd(II) ion acts as a square four-connected node, while each bix serves as a 2-connecter spacer. Thus, whole framework of 1 is a threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework (Fig. 4e, f). An analysis of the interpenetration fashion with the TOPOS program [25] reveals that it belongs to class Ia with the translating interpenetration vector being equal to the a axis (9.43 Å).
elements.clean_text: Another striking feature of 1 is the presence of an entangled motif between nine 104-membered rings (1 + 8); i.e., through shared Cd(II), each 104-membered ring is connected with other eight adjacent 104-membered rings (Fig. 4a-c)]. In this way, these 104-membered rings are interlinked to give a 3D coordination framework (Fig. 4d). Owing to the large available space, three such 3D networks interpenetrate each other into a threefold framework. Topologically, each Cd(II) ion acts as a square four-connected node, while each bix serves as a 2-connecter spacer. Thus, whole framework of 1 is a threefold interpenetrating 42 × 84-lvt framework (Fig. 4e, f). An analysis of the interpenetration fashion with the TOPOS program [25] reveals that it belongs to class Ia with the translating interpenetration vector being equal to the a axis (9.43 Å).

elements.content: The XRPD was used to confirm the phase purity of bulk materials of 1 at room temperature (Fig. 5). Although the experimental pattern shows several unindexed or slightly broadened diffraction peaks relative to those simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk synthesized material represents the pure phase of 1. There was no evidence of crystal decay during X-ray data collection for 1, which is stable at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
XPRD and Thermogravimetric Analysis

The XRPD was used to confirm the phase purity of bulk materials of 1 at room temperature (Fig. 5). Although the experimental pattern shows several unindexed or slightly broadened diffraction peaks relative to those simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk synthesized material represents the pure phase of 1. There was no evidence of crystal decay during X-ray data collection for 1, which is stable at ambient conditions.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have been extensively investigated for fluorescence properties with potential applications as chemical sensors, in photochemistry, and as light emitting diodes [26, 27]. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescent spectrum of 1 was measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense emission band at 461 nm (λex = 352 nm) (Fig. 7). Relative to the free bix ligand (maxima at 359 nm upon excitation 318 nm [28]), the emission maxima of 1 is changed. Since the CdII ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce, the emission peak for 1 is neither a metal-to-ligand nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer in nature, but may arise from π* → π transitions of the bix ligand. As evidence, a similar peak appears for other complexes containing bix ligand [28–30].
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Property

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have been extensively investigated for fluorescence properties with potential applications as chemical sensors, in photochemistry, and as light emitting diodes [26, 27]. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescent spectrum of 1 was measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense emission band at 461 nm (λex = 352 nm) (Fig. 7). Relative to the free bix ligand (maxima at 359 nm upon excitation 318 nm [28]), the emission maxima of 1 is changed. Since the CdII ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce, the emission peak for 1 is neither a metal-to-ligand nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer in nature, but may arise from π* → π transitions of the bix ligand. As evidence, a similar peak appears for other complexes containing bix ligand [28-30].

elements.content: A novel 3D threefold interpenetrated lvt coordination framework, which is constructed from a rare 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)]816+, with a chair configuration was synthesized and characterized. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link CdII centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ subuints. Through the shared CdII, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a 3D threefold interpenetrating lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel 3D threefold interpenetrated lvt coordination framework, which is constructed from a rare 104-membered ring, [Cd(bix)]816+, with a chair configuration was synthesized and characterized. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, TG, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The bix ligand adopts a gauche-configuration to alternately link CdII centers into a rare 104-membered ring with a chair-configuration containing eight repetitive [-Cd-bix-]2+ subuints. Through the shared CdII, the adjacent 104-membered rings are interconnected into a 3D threefold interpenetrating lvt framework. The thermal stability and photoluminescence property of 1 is also investigated.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA of 1 was performed in air from 30 to 800 °C. The TGA curve shows that the anhydrous 1 is stable to 245 °C. The framework of 1 gradually collapses on further heating and probably corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands (Fig. 6).

Luminescent Property

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have been extensively investigated for fluorescence properties with potential applications as chemical sensors, in photochemistry, and as light emitting diodes [26, 27]. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescent spectrum of 1 was measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense emission band at 461 nm (λex = 352 nm) (Fig. 7). Relative to the free bix ligand (maxima at 359 nm upon excitation 318 nm [28]), the emission maxima of 1 is changed. Since the CdII ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce, the emission peak for 1 is neither a metal-to-ligand nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer in nature, but may arise from π* → π transitions of the bix ligand. As evidence, a similar peak appears for other complexes containing bix ligand [28–30].
